{{Construct analysis |text=in poverty |Entered by=Oana |Status=in development |construction=Locative-PP |frames=In |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=in |constituent.cxn=In |constituent.frames=In }} |bindings= |metaphors= |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=in poverty |informalanalysis=What are the metaphors and framings surrounding poverty? Poverty is a lack of resources, by being a lack of a resource (money) for those resources. What are the facets of ‘poverty’ that are likely to be picked out by different constructions? • Scalar nature of poverty/wealth (“climbing out of poverty”) • Static vs. dynamic nature of states (“being in poverty” vs. “getting out of poverty”) o STATES ARE LOCATIONS (BOUNDED REGIONS); Therefore, POVERTY IS A BOUNDED REGION. • Poverty as a causal force (“poverty attacks”) • Poverty is a circumstance (CIRCUMSTANCES ARE STATES)
|Entered by=Oana |Status=in development |construction=Locative-PP |frames=In |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=in |constituent.cxn=In |constituent.frames=In }} |bindings= |metaphors= |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=in poverty |informalanalysis=Notes on "poverty":
What are the metaphors and framings surrounding poverty? Poverty is a lack of resources, by being a lack of a resource (money) for those resources. What are the facets of ‘poverty’ that are likely to be picked out by different constructions? • Scalar nature of poverty/wealth (“climbing out of poverty”) • Static vs. dynamic nature of states (“being in poverty” vs. “getting out of poverty”) o STATES ARE LOCATIONS (BOUNDED REGIONS); Therefore, POVERTY IS A BOUNDED REGION. • Poverty as a causal force (“poverty attacks”) • Poverty is a circumstance (CIRCUMSTANCES ARE STATES) |Entered by=Oana |Status=in development |construction=Locative-PP |frames=In |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=in |constituent.cxn=In |constituent.frames=In }} |bindings= |metaphors= |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=in poverty |informalanalysis=Notes on "poverty" (will be moved to the appropriate location(s) when they become available):
Needs notion of Resources (which is inherently purpose-driven). Money is about Resources. Money is a resource for resources. Poverty is a lack of resources, by being a lack of a resource (money) for those resources.
What are the metaphors and framings surrounding poverty? Well-being frame: The goal of getting out of poverty is flourishing. Types of well-being include: wealth, health, education, happiness, respect (positive social status), self-esteem, etc. Frames and metaphors pick out different ones of the latter.
E.g.: Access to education is a special case of having a path with no impediments to education as a form of well-being and a resource for other forms of well-being.
What are the facets of ‘poverty’ that are likely to be picked out by different constructions? • Scalar nature of poverty/wealth (“climbing out of poverty”) • Static vs. dynamic nature of states (“being in poverty” vs. “getting out of poverty”) o STATES ARE LOCATIONS (BOUNDED REGIONS); Therefore, POVERTY IS A BOUNDED REGION. • Poverty as a causal force (“poverty attacks”) • Poverty is a circumstance (CIRCUMSTANCES ARE STATES) |Entered by=Oana |Status=in development |construction=Locative-PP |frames=In |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=in |constituent.cxn=In |constituent.frames=In }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor}} |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=in poverty |informalanalysis=Notes on "poverty" (will be moved to the appropriate location(s) when they become available):
Needs notion of Resources (which is inherently purpose-driven). Money is about Resources. Money is a resource for resources. Poverty is a lack of resources, by being a lack of a resource (money) for those resources.
What are the metaphors and framings surrounding poverty? Well-being frame: The goal of getting out of poverty is flourishing. Types of well-being include: wealth, health, education, happiness, respect (positive social status), self-esteem, etc. Frames and metaphors pick out different ones of the latter.
E.g.: Access to education is a special case of having a path with no impediments to education as a form of well-being and a resource for other forms of well-being.
Inferences about being in poverty: 1. Have difficulty getting the forms of well-being 2. There are forces acting on you / lead you to forms of ill-being, e.g., gang membership, depression. (But gang-membership is a way to get social status/resources/wealth.)
What are the facets of ‘poverty’ that are likely to be picked out by different constructions? • Scalar nature of poverty/wealth (“climbing out of poverty”) • Static vs. dynamic nature of states (“being in poverty” vs. “getting out of poverty”) o STATES ARE LOCATIONS (BOUNDED REGIONS); Therefore, POVERTY IS A BOUNDED REGION. • Poverty as a causal force (“poverty attacks”) • Poverty is a circumstance (CIRCUMSTANCES ARE STATES) |Entered by=Oana |Status=in development |construction=Locative-PP |frames=In |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=in |constituent.cxn=In |constituent.frames=In }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor}} |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=in poverty |informalanalysis=Notes on "poverty" (will be moved to the appropriate location(s) when they become available):
Needs notion of Resources (which is inherently purpose-driven). Money is about Resources. Money is a resource for resources. Poverty is a lack of resources, by being a lack of a resource (money) for those resources.
What are the metaphors and framings surrounding poverty? Well-being frame: The goal of getting out of poverty is flourishing. Types of well-being include: wealth, health, education, happiness, respect (positive social status), self-esteem, etc. Frames and metaphors pick out different ones of the latter.
E.g.: Access to education is a special case of having a path with no impediments to education as a form of well-being and a resource for other forms of well-being.
Inferences about being in poverty: 1. Have difficulty getting the forms of well-being 2. There are forces acting on you / lead you to forms of ill-being, e.g., gang membership, depression. (But gang-membership is a way to get social status/resources/wealth.)
What are the facets of ‘poverty’ that are likely to be picked out by different constructions? • Scalar nature of poverty/wealth (“climbing out of poverty”) • Static vs. dynamic nature of states (“being in poverty” vs. “getting out of poverty”) o STATES ARE LOCATIONS (BOUNDED REGIONS); Therefore, POVERTY IS A BOUNDED REGION. • Poverty as a causal force (“poverty attacks”) • Poverty is a circumstance (CIRCUMSTANCES ARE STATES) |Entered by=Oana |Status=in development |construction=Locative-PP |frames=In |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=in |constituent.cxn=In |constituent.frames=In }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor |metaphor.metaphor=POVERTY IS A BOUNDED REGION |metaphor.evokingsourceelements=in |metaphor.evokingtargetelements=poverty }} |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=in poverty |informalanalysis=Notes on "poverty" (will be moved to the appropriate location(s) when they become available):
Needs notion of Resources (which is inherently purpose-driven). Money is about Resources. Money is a resource for resources. Poverty is a lack of resources, by being a lack of a resource (money) for those resources.
What are the metaphors and framings surrounding poverty? Well-being frame: The goal of getting out of poverty is flourishing. Types of well-being include: wealth, health, education, happiness, respect (positive social status), self-esteem, etc. Frames and metaphors pick out different ones of the latter.
E.g.: Access to education is a special case of having a path with no impediments to education as a form of well-being and a resource for other forms of well-being.
Inferences about being in poverty: 1. Have difficulty getting the forms of well-being 2. There are forces acting on you / lead you to forms of ill-being, e.g., gang membership, depression. (But gang-membership is a way to get social status/resources/wealth.)
What are the facets of ‘poverty’ that are likely to be picked out by different constructions? • Scalar nature of poverty/wealth (“climbing out of poverty”) • Static vs. dynamic nature of states (“being in poverty” vs. “getting out of poverty”) o STATES ARE LOCATIONS (BOUNDED REGIONS); Therefore, POVERTY IS A BOUNDED REGION. • Poverty as a causal force (“poverty attacks”) • Poverty is a circumstance (CIRCUMSTANCES ARE STATES) |Entered by=Oana |Status=in development |construction=Locative-PP |frames=In |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=in |constituent.cxn=In |constituent.frames=In }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor |metaphor.metaphor=EXPERIENCING AN ECONOMIC STATUS IS BEING AT A LOCATION |metaphor.evokingsourceelements=in |metaphor.evokingtargetelements=poverty }} |examples= }}

revision.text: {{Construct analysis |text=veneer of democracy |Entered by=Ellen Elise Oana |Status=in development |constituents= |bindings= |metaphors= |examples={{CA example |example.language=English |example.text=as little more than political theater, an orchestrated show with a veneer of democracy overlaying the regime's fiercely autocratic core. |example.provenance=content.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2114140,00.html‎ }}{{CA example |example.language=English |example.text=Ordinarily, political scientists think of elections in authoritarian nations as charades aimed at giving a veneer of democracy to undemocratic systems. |example.provenance=books.google.com/books?isbn=041517208X }} }}

revision.comment: Created page with "{{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses a role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that betwe..."
revision.text: {{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses a role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that between the 'burden' role in the Burden frame, and 'tax' role in the Taxation frame. |comment=This mapping can also be expressed using the NP(T)copula NP(S) cxn (e.g. Taxes are a burden) |Entered by=Ellen |Status=in development |construction=N_of_N |constituents= |bindings= |metaphors= |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses an entity-to-entity role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that between the 'burden' role in the Burden frame, and 'tax' role in the Taxation frame. |comment=This mapping can also be expressed using the NP(T)copula NP(S) cxn (e.g. Taxes are a burden) |Entered by=Ellen |Status=in development |construction=N_of_N |constituents= |bindings= |metaphors= |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses an entity-to-entity role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that between the 'burden' role in the Burden frame, and 'tax' role in the Taxation frame.
To 'automatically' identify the role-filler relations involved here, it seems like we would have to associate the LUs to their relevant frame roles (e.g. burden.n, load.n would be linked to 'burden' role of Burden frame). |comment=This mapping can also be expressed using the NP(T)copula NP(S) cxn (e.g. Taxes are a burden) |Entered by=Ellen |Status=in development |construction=N_of_N |cxncomments=We need to define which subcase of N_of_N this is. It may be that it is exclusively metaphorical (unlike, e.g. Part_of_whole, or Container_of_Contents N_of_N cxns). |constituents= |bindings= |metaphors= |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses an entity-to-entity role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that between the 'burden' role in the Burden frame, and 'tax' role in the Taxation frame.
To 'automatically' identify the role-filler relations involved here, it seems like we would have to associate the LUs to their relevant frame roles (e.g. burden.n, load.n would be linked to 'burden' role of Burden frame).
Note that both of the 'N' constituents can include modifiers, e.g 'heavy burden of unfair taxation' |comment=This mapping can also be expressed using the NP(T)copula NP(S) cxn (e.g. Taxes are a burden).
We need to define which subcase of N_of_N this is. It may be that it is exclusively metaphorical (unlike, e.g. Part_of_whole, or Container_of_Contents N_of_N cxns). Or, it may be related to something like 'the elected position of president', which seems to be similar to 'president is an elected position'. This in turn is similar to 'president is a instance/type of elected position'. So we might characterize this N_of_N as 'Category of Instance'?? |Entered by=Ellen |Status=in development |construction=N_of_N |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=burden |constituent.frames=Burden }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=of }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=taxation |constituent.frames=Taxation }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor |metaphor.metaphor=TAXATION IS A BURDEN |metaphor.evokingsourceelements=Burden |metaphor.evokingtargetelements=Taxation }} |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses an entity-to-entity role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that between the 'burden' role in the Burden frame, and 'tax' role in the Taxation frame.
To 'automatically' identify the role-filler relations involved here, it seems like we would have to associate the LUs to their relevant frame roles (e.g. burden.n, load.n would be linked to 'burden' role of Burden frame).
Note that both of the 'N' constituents can include modifiers, e.g 'heavy burden of unfair taxation' |comment=This mapping can also be expressed using the NP(T)copula NP(S) cxn (e.g. Taxes are a burden).
We need to define which subcase of N_of_N this is. It may be that it is exclusively metaphorical (unlike, e.g. Part_of_whole, or Container_of_Contents N_of_N cxns). Or, it may be related to something like 'the elected office of president', which seems to be similar to 'president is an elected office'. This in turn is similar to 'president is a instance/type of elected position'. So we might characterize this N_of_N as 'Category of Instance'?? |Entered by=Ellen |Status=in development |construction=N_of_N |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=burden |constituent.frames=Burden }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=of }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=taxation |constituent.frames=Taxation }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor |metaphor.metaphor=TAXATION IS A BURDEN |metaphor.evokingsourceelements=Burden |metaphor.evokingtargetelements=Taxation }} |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses an entity-to-entity role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that between the 'burden' role in the Burden frame, and 'tax' role in the Taxation frame.
To 'automatically' identify the relevant source and target roles involved here, it seems like we would have to associate the LUs to their relevant frame roles (e.g. burden.n, load.n would be linked to the 'burden' role of Burden frame, and taxation.n and tax.n would be linked to the 'tax' role of the Taxation frame).
Note that both of the 'N' constituents can include modifiers, e.g 'heavy burden of unfair taxation' |comment=This mapping can also be expressed using the NP(T)copula NP(S) cxn (e.g. Taxes are a burden).
We need to define which subcase of N_of_N this is. It may be that it is exclusively metaphorical (unlike, e.g. Part_of_whole, or Container_of_Contents N_of_N cxns). Or, it may be related to examples such as 'the burden of heavy backpacks', which might also be expressed as 'heavy backpacks are a burden'. Similarly, we have patterns like 'the elected office of president', and president is an elected office'. It is unclear how exactly to characterize the semantic relations expressed in these examples. |Entered by=Ellen |Status=in development |construction=N_of_N |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=burden |constituent.frames=Burden }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=of }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=taxation |constituent.frames=Taxation }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor |metaphor.metaphor=TAXATION IS A BURDEN |metaphor.evokingsourceelements=burden.v |metaphor.evokingtargetelements=taxation.n }} |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses an entity-to-entity role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that between the 'burden' role in the Burden frame, and 'tax' role in the Taxation frame.
To 'automatically' identify the relevant source and target roles involved here, it seems like we would have to associate the LUs to their relevant frame roles (e.g. burden.n, load.n would be linked to the 'burden' role of Burden frame, and taxation.n and tax.n would be linked to the 'tax' role of the Taxation frame).
Note that both of the 'N' constituents can include modifiers, e.g 'heavy burden of unfair taxation' |comment=This mapping can also be expressed using the NP(T)copula NP(S) cxn (e.g. Taxes are a burden).
We need to define which subcase of N_of_N this is. It may be that it is exclusively metaphorical (unlike, e.g. Part_of_whole, or Container_of_Contents N_of_N cxns). Or, it may be related to examples such as 'the burden of heavy backpacks', which might also be expressed as 'heavy backpacks are a burden'. Similarly, we have patterns like 'the elected office of president', and president is an elected office'. It is unclear how exactly to characterize the semantic relations expressed in these examples. |Entered by=Ellen |Status=in development |construction=N of N |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=burden |constituent.frames=Burden }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=of }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=taxation |constituent.frames=Taxation }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor |metaphor.metaphor=TAXATION IS A BURDEN |metaphor.evokingsourceelements=burden.v |metaphor.evokingtargetelements=taxation.n }} |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses an entity-to-entity role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that between the 'burden' role in the Burden frame, and 'tax' role in the Taxation frame.
To 'automatically' identify the relevant source and target roles involved here, it seems like we would have to associate the LUs to their relevant frame roles (e.g. burden.n, load.n would be linked to the 'burden' role of Burden frame, and taxation.n and tax.n would be linked to the 'tax' role of the Taxation frame).
Note that both of the 'N' constituents can include modifiers, e.g 'heavy burden of unfair taxation' |comment=This mapping can also be expressed using the NP(T)copula NP(S) cxn (e.g. Taxes are a burden).
We need to define which subcase of N_of_N this is. It may be that it is exclusively metaphorical (unlike, e.g. Part_of_whole, or Container_of_Contents N_of_N cxns). Or, it may be related to examples such as 'the burden of heavy backpacks', which might also be expressed as 'heavy backpacks are a burden'. Similarly, we have patterns like 'the elected office of president', and president is an elected office'. It is unclear how exactly to characterize the semantic relations expressed in these examples. |Entered by=Ellen |Status=in development |construction=Veneer of democracy |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=burden |constituent.frames=Burden }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=of }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=taxation |constituent.frames=Taxation }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor |metaphor.metaphor=TAXATION IS A BURDEN |metaphor.evokingsourceelements=burden.v |metaphor.evokingtargetelements=taxation.n }} |examples= }}

{{Construct analysis |text=burden of taxation |informalanalysis=This N(S)of N(T) construct expresses an entity-to-entity role mapping within the TAXATION IS A BURDEN metaphor, namely that between the 'burden' role in the Burden frame, and 'tax' role in the Taxation frame.
To 'automatically' identify the relevant source and target roles involved here, it seems like we would have to associate the LUs to their relevant frame roles (e.g. burden.n, load.n would be linked to the 'burden' role of Burden frame, and taxation.n and tax.n would be linked to the 'tax' role of the Taxation frame).
Note that both of the 'N' constituents can include modifiers, e.g 'heavy burden of unfair taxation' |comment=This mapping can also be expressed using the NP(T)copula NP(S) cxn (e.g. Taxes are a burden).
We need to define which subcase of N_of_N this is. It may be that it is exclusively metaphorical (unlike, e.g. Part_of_whole, or Container_of_Contents N_of_N cxns). Or, it may be related to examples such as 'the burden of heavy backpacks', which might also be expressed as 'heavy backpacks are a burden'. Similarly, we have patterns like 'the elected office of president', and president is an elected office'. It is unclear how exactly to characterize the semantic relations expressed in these examples. |Entered by=Ellen |Status=in development |construction=N of N |constituents={{CA constituent |constituent.string=burden |constituent.frames=Burden }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=of }}{{CA constituent |constituent.string=taxation |constituent.frames=Taxation }} |bindings= |metaphors={{CA metaphor |metaphor.metaphor=TAXATION IS A BURDEN |metaphor.evokingsourceelements=burden.v |metaphor.evokingtargetelements=taxation.n }} |examples= }}
